chapter.htmlHeader: What else might it be?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
Alternative conditions that may present similarly to a stye include:

  • Benign eyelid cysts.
    • Meibomian cyst (chalazion). See the CKS topic on Meibomian cyst (chalazion) for more information.
    • Cysts of Moll — arise from blocked apocrine sweat glands on the eyelid margin. They are typically dome-shaped papules or nodules filled with clear fluid.
    • Cysts of Zeis — arise from blocked sebaceous glands on the eyelid margin. They are typically filled with yellow oily secretions.
    • Epidermal inclusion cyst — arise from occlusion of the infundibulum of the hair follicle. They are typically slow-growing, firm, elevated, round lesions that have a central pore and are filled with keratin.
  • Contact dermatitis. See the CKS topic on Dermatitis - contact for more information.
  • Atopic eczema. See the CKS topic on Eczema - atopic for more information.
  • Blepharitis. See the CKS topic on Blepharitis for more information.
  • Dacryocystitis (infection of the lacrimal sac caused by a blocked nasolacrimal duct).
    • In acute infection, there is pain, oedema, and erythema localized in the medial canthal region (which may extend to the nose and cheek).
    • In chronic infection, there may be no oedema or erythema, but massage of the skin over the lacrimal sac may result in purulent discharge seen at the lacrimal punctum.
  • Acne rosacea. See the CKS topic on Rosacea - acne for more information.
  • Herpes zoster infection. See the CKS topic on Shingles for more information.
  • Herpes simplex infection. See the CKS topic on Herpes simplex - ocular for more information.
  • Periorbital and orbital cellulitis. See the CKS topic on Cellulitis - acute for more information.
  • Malignant eyelid tumours.
    • May be suggested by atypical clinical features (such as progressive skin lesions, distortion or destruction of the eyelid margin, loss of eyelashes, pigmentation, irregular border, ulceration, crusting, or bleeding), or a suspected stye recurring in the same location.
    • May be caused by basal cell carcinoma (most common), melanoma, sebaceous cell carcinoma, or squamous cell carcinoma. See the CKS topic on Skin cancers - recognition and referral for more information.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The information on the differential diagnosis of a stye is based on the College of Optometrists clinical management guideline Hordeolum [College of Optometrists, 2018] and expert opinion in review articles on eyelid lesions [Peralejo et al, 2008; Gupta et al, 2014; Carlisle, 2015; Pflipsen, 2016; Sun, 2019] and on other eye conditions [Mueller and McStay, 2008].

  • The information on the clinical features of benign eyelid cysts is based on expert opinion in review articles [Gupta et al, 2014; Sun, 2019].
  • The information on the clinical features of dacryocystitis is based on expert opinion in review articles [Mueller and McStay, 2008; Gupta et al, 2014].
  • The information on the possible clinical features of malignant eyelid tumours is based on expert opinion in review articles [Gupta et al, 2014; Sun, 2019].
